The viewer id of the map pane that will export the map. When the viewerID = -1, the mapPath is used to find any viewers that contain the map path. If one it found then it will be used to export. If no map viewer for the current map path is found, then a new viewer is created for the map path.
Path to the output file.
The Export type.
Dots per inch X.

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Internal.Mapping.Controls.QueryBuilder.QueryBuilderComboBox
member.summary:
Follow steps 1a or 1b and then 2 to use this custom control in a XAML file.
Step 1a) Using this custom control in a XAML file that exists in the current project. Add this XmlNamespace attribute to the root element of the markup file where it is to be used:
xmlns:MyNamespace="clr-namespace:ArcGIS.Desktop.Internal.Mapping.Controls.QueryBuilder"
Step 1b) Using this custom control in a XAML file that exists in a different project. Add this XmlNamespace attribute to the root element of the markup file where it is to be used:
xmlns:MyNamespace="clr-namespace:ArcGIS.Desktop.Internal.Mapping.Controls.QueryBuilder;assembly=ArcGIS.Desktop.Internal.Mapping.Controls.QueryBuilder"
You will also need to add a project reference from the project where the XAML file lives to this project and Rebuild to avoid compilation errors:
Right click on the target project in the Solution Explorer and "Add Reference"->"Projects"->[Browse to and select this project]
Step 2) Go ahead and use your control in the XAML file.
<MyNamespace:QueryBuilderComboBox/>
Step 3) Provide an UIElement for the PopupContent. The contents of the ComboBox and be displayed in a ScrollViewer or an ItemsControl found in the UIElement.
To use a ScrollViewer, name it in the UIElement and set the PopupScrollViewerName property of the ComboBox to the same name. NOTE: CURRENTLY SETTING THE SCROLLVIEWER WILL CAUSE VIRTUALIZATION WITH A VIRTUALIZINGSTACKPANEL TO FAIL!
To use a ItemsControl, name it in the UIElement and set the PopupItemsControlName property of the ComboBox to the same name.
If both items are provided the ScrollViewer will be used.

member.summary: Flag indicating the mouse button is not pressed.

member.summary: Keys that should ignored, when the mouse down is received. When the keys are active the navigation action will not start.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Internal.Mapping.Controls.ViewerMouseAction.IsActive
member.summary: Flag indicating that the current action is actively listening to events. This is the case from the call to start and the execution of the action has been completed.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Internal.Mapping.Controls.ViewerMouseAction.IsTimerActive
member.summary: Flag indicating the timer is active.

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Internal.Mapping.Controls.ViewerMouseAction.Start(ArcGIS.Desktop.Internal.Mapping.Win32.POINT)
member.summary:
Function called when we want to start listening to mouse events and we want to start our action.
This function is called by the ExploreNavigation when it received a mouse down message.
If the action is a timed action, a timer will be started. The duration of the timer will be the double click system time. If the timer fires, then the action will be executed. If the Stop function is called, the timer will be aborted.
member.param: Click location at start of action.

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Internal.Mapping.Controls.ViewerMouseAction.Stop(System.Int32)
member.summary:
This function is used to cancel the mouse down action.
This function is called by the ExploreNavigation when it receives a mouse move or double click message.

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Internal.Mapping.Controls.ViewerMouseAction.ButtonUp(System.Int32)
member.summary: This function is called by the ExploreNavigation when it receives a mouse up message.
member.param: State of the keyboard.

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Internal.Mapping.Controls.ViewerMouseAction.Execute
member.summary:
Function called to execute the mouse down action.
Called from the action timer or from the ButtonUp function.
member.returns: true - The action was executed. false - The action was not executed.

member.summary: Timer callback function, used to execute the timed action.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Internal.Mapping.DesignView.AttributeRules.MonotonicityRuleViewModel.NonMonotonicValuesAreError
member.summary: Boolean value indicating if a feature should be returned as validation result when it's vertices are not strictly increasing or decreasing in value. The From node of the feature is used as the point of reference when comparing vertex values. The default value is false.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Internal.Mapping.DesignView.AttributeRules.MonotonicityRuleViewModel.LevelValuesAreError
member.summary: Boolean value indicating if a feature should be returned as validation result when it's From node is equal to the To node. The default value is false.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Internal.Mapping.DesignView.AttributeRules.MonotonicityRuleViewModel.MonotonicityDirection
member.summary: Boolean value indicating if a feature should be returned as validation result when it's vertices are not strictly increasing or decreasing in value. The From node of the feature is used as the point of reference when comparing vertex values. The default value is false.

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Internal.Mapping.DesignView.AttributeRules.MonotonicityRuleViewModel.SetErrorDescriptionAndNumber
member.summary:
Method to set error description and code based on user selected values. Possible error number and messages 229, Polyline changes slope direction (Non monotonic Z) 801, Slope trends in an illegal direction (Z - Level, Increasing, Decreasing)
800, No Measure (NaN) values (Invalid M values) 802, Feature is non-monotonic (Non-monotonic M) 803, Feature From/To M-values are equal (M Level) 804, Feature From/To M-values are increasing (M Increasing) 805, Feature From/To M-values are decreasing (M Decreasing)

member.summary:
This property can potentially return a invalid /not hydrated struct. There are 2 distinct workflows which required it. 1. Loading a persisted set of Attribute rules 2. Adding a new Reviewer rule.
Both the above workflows have been handled correctly to hydrate this property. The correct implementation woudl be to chance Add Rule workfow to construct and initialize Async for supportin async initialization. This is a TODO for later release.

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Internal.Mapping.Views.PropertyPage.MapPropertiesManager
member.summary:
MapPropertiesManager stores the map definition of all maps for which the user has opened the property page.
Individual property pages must use the MapPropertiesManager to get the map definition(s) they need during initialization, and during commit update any needed properties and set MapDefinitionModified to true.
Individual property pages must never store a local copy of the map definition nor must they call any native methods that update the map definition during commit

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Internal.Mapping.Views.PropertyPage.LayerPropertiesManager
member.summary:
LayerPropertiesManager stores the layer definition of all layers for which the user has opened the property page.
Individual property pages must use the LayerPropertiesManager to get the layer definition(s) they need during initialization, and during commit update any needed properties and set LayerDefinitionModified to true.
Individual property pages must never store a local copy of the layer definition nor must they call any native methods that update the layer definition during commit

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Internal.Mapping.TOC.TOCKMLFeatureViewModel
member.summary:
The base class for all KML features in the TOC.
This class has a strong reference to a native IKMLFeature. Normally this pattern is frowned upon in Pro, but the native KMLFeature COM object is designed to be thread-neutral, so this is OK. This class's Dispose() implementation releases the reference, and the KMLFeature has a normal, ref-counted lifetime.
The threads we use in the Pro UI (the main thread, and the main worker thread) are STA, so calls into the native KMLFeature (which is MTA) do require COM marshaling, in addition to the usual interop marshaling. If this proves to be a bottleneck, we should batch up the chatty interop calls.

member.param:
Tuple<int, int> - index of edited row, index of edited column
Column Index
0 - IsVisible - can be edited but handled using SelectedUniqueValue.PropertyChanged
1 - Symbol - can be edited but handled using Command
2 - Value - cannot be edited
3 - Label - can be edited

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Internal.Mapping.Symbology.DotDensitySymbolizerViewModel.ResizeValueExpressionInfos(ArcGIS.Core.CIM.CIMDotDensityRenderer)
member.summary: Helper function to ensure CIM Renderer's ValueExpressionInfos property is correctly resized to match with FieldNames array so that we dont hit with array out of bounds erros. Also we need to all these arrays to be in equal size to support restoring fieldname/expression in the same order in which they are created. Also whenever we are setting expression, we are assigning fieldname to string.empty to avoid confusion.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Internal.Mapping.Symbology.HeatMapSymbolizerViewModel.Field
member.summary: Name of the field denoting weighting values for each feature. The field's value is the count or quantity to be spread across the landscape to create a continuous surface. Values in the field may be integer or floating point. The options for the field are listed below. Specify the name of a numeric field in the feature table. Use "" if no item or special value will be used and each feature will be counted once. Use Shape if input features contains Z.

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Internal.Mapping.Symbology.GridSplitterMaxHeightConverter
member.summary: This converter adds the returns the result of value+parameter, where both objects are assumed to be doubles. This converter is used to update DataRow.MaxHeight when a Grid Splitter is used. When the DataRow.MaxHeight is not limited it is possible to drag the Grid Splitter control out of view, thus loosing the capability to resize the grid as the Grid Splitter is not available.

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Internal.Mapping.ScalesHelper.ToCIM(System.Double,System.Boolean,ArcGIS.Desktop.Internal.Core.LinearDisplayUnit,System.Boolean)
member.summary:
Converts a Managed Scale or Height to CIM value.
On the managed side, unused scale/height levels are stored as NaN whereas in the CIM they are stored as -1. Also on the managed side, 3D distance is shown in default linear units whereas in the CIM they are stored as meters.
member.param: Scale or height to convert
It's a Scale for 2D maps.
The display unit for 3D heights.
Allow negative values
member.returns: The CIM value for the Scale or Height.

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Internal.Mapping.ScalesHelper.ToCIMScale(System.Double,System.Boolean)
member.summary:
Convert Managed Scale to CIM value.
On the managed side, unused scale/height levels are stored as NaN whereas in the CIM they are stored as -1. Also on the managed side, 3D distance is shown in default linear units whereas in the CIM they are stored as meters.
member.param: Scale or height to convert
Allow negative values
member.returns: The CIM value for the Scale or Height.

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Internal.Mapping.ScalesHelper.ToCIMHeight(System.Double,ArcGIS.Desktop.Internal.Core.LinearDisplayUnit,System.Boolean)
member.summary:
Convert Managed 3D Height to CIM value.
On the managed side, unused scale/height levels are stored as NaN whereas in the CIM they are stored as -1. Also on the managed side, 3D distance is shown in default linear units whereas in the CIM they are stored as meters.
member.param: Scale or height to convert
The display unit for 3D heights.
Allow negative values
member.returns: The CIM value for the Scale or Height.

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Internal.Mapping.ScalesHelper.FromCIMScale(System.Double,System.Boolean)
member.summary:
Convert a CIM scale to a managed value.
On the managed side, unused scale/height levels are stored as NaN whereas in the CIM they are stored as -1. Also on the managed side, 3D distance is shown in default linear units whereas in the CIM they are stored as meters.
member.param: CIM Scale to convert.
Allow negative for conversion.
member.returns: A managed scale value

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Internal.Mapping.ScalesHelper.FromCIMHeight(System.Double,ArcGIS.Desktop.Internal.Core.LinearDisplayUnit,System.Boolean)
member.summary:
Convert a CIM height to a managed value.
On the managed side, unused scale/height levels are stored as NaN whereas in the CIM they are stored as -1. Also on the managed side, 3D distance is shown in default linear units whereas in the CIM they are stored as meters.
member.param: Height to convert.
Linear display unit to convert from.
Allow negative for conversion.
member.returns: A managed height value

Custom List of Scales or Distances for the map view. This are the scales and distances that the user types into the scale controls to navigate the map view. They are not persited, so they are lost when the App is closed.
When Is2D is true, these are Scales. When Is2D is false, these are Distances.

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Internal.Mapping.InternalSymbolExtensionMethods.AddLOD(ArcGIS.Core.CIM.CIMObjectMarker3D,System.String)
member.summary: Adds an additional LOD to an existing ObjectMarker3D. This method must be called on the MCT. Use QueuedTask.Run.
member.remarks: It is recommended that CIMObjectMarker3D.ModelURI be an intermediate representation of your 3D model in terms of geometry and texture complexity. AddLOD can be used to add more detailed or more coarse representations of the same 3D model.
member.param: The path to the 3D model file that represents the additional LOD.
member.returns: A bool indicating whether the LOD was successfully added.
member.exception: This method must be called within the lambda passed to QueuedTask.Run
File doesn't exist
LOD already exists
Call to add the LOD failed

members.member:
Removes an existing LOD from an ObjectMarker3D. This method must be called on the MCT. Use QueuedTask.Run.
The primary LOD cannot be removed. ///
The index of the LOD to remove. A bool indicating whether the LOD was successfully removed. This method must be called within the lambda passed to QueuedTask.Run The primary LOD cannot be removed LOD doesn't exist Call to remove the LOD failed

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Internal.Mapping.TOCActiveMapViewProviderPaneSettings
member.summary:
Class to manage the active map pane id for the TOCActiveMapViewProviderPane panes.
This id are used when the TOCActiveMapViewProviderPane is initialized and its target map pane has not been initialized and is not ready to find its map view.
This is the case for LayoutPanes. So if a TOCActiveMapViewProviderPane and a LayoutPane are saved with a project, this ids can be used to associate the panes and keep from closing Permanent TOCActiveMapViewProviderPane panes.

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Internal.DesktopService.LevelComputeMethod
member.summary: Methods for computing levels for multi-level visual variable (used for binning).

member.name: F:ArcGIS.Desktop.Internal.DesktopService.LevelComputeMethod.ReadCached
member.summary: Recompute levels by reading cached statistics from DBMS metadata. Fail if cached statistics don't exist.

member.name: F:ArcGIS.Desktop.Internal.DesktopService.LevelComputeMethod.ReadCachedOrRequery
member.summary: Recompute levels by reading cached statistics from DBMS metadata. If cached statistics don't exist, requery from data.

member.name: F:ArcGIS.Desktop.Internal.DesktopService.LevelComputeMethod.RequeryFromData
member.summary: Recompute levels by querying the database directly. Results are then cached in DBMS metadata.

member.name: F:ArcGIS.Desktop.Internal.DesktopService.LevelComputeMethod.RequeryFromDataNoRecache
member.summary: Recompute levels by querying the database directly. Results are NOT cached in DBMS metadata.

member.name: F:ArcGIS.Desktop.Internal.DesktopService.LevelComputeMethod.Remultiply
member.summary: Recompute levels by applying multiplier to statistics already stored in the layer.

member.summary: Open KML file in 2D mode.

member.summary: Open KML file in 3D mode.

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Internal.KML.IKMLService.OpenKMLFile(System.String,ArcGIS.Desktop.Internal.KML.KMLFileMode,System.String,System.Int32)
member.summary: Opens a KML file. Passing KML2D or KML3D for "mode" will open a file from scratch; passing KMLWhatever will fail if a file hasn't already been opened. Pass "layerURI" and "viewerID" to get unique instances for each layer and/or viewer using this file. If you don't care which instance of a given file you get, pass NULL and -1, respectively.

member.summary: Subscribe to the LayersRemovingEvent.

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Geocoding.LocatorManager.AddLocatorAsync(System.String)
member.summary: Add a locator to the set of available locators.
member.param: provider path. Can be a local file (ending in .loc) or a online geocode service.
member.returns: Task of bool indicating success or failure.
member.remarks: Three different types of locators are supported : Local locators - example: D:\\Data\\Geocode\\ACT.loc Locators shared to portal - example: https://portal/server/rest/services/locatorName/GeocodeServer Geocoding services associated with an ArcGIS Server connection "ags" file - example: C:\\path\\my_ags_server\\locatorName.GeocodeServer". Note: the suffix .GeocodeServer is required. "C:\\path\\my_ags_server" is the fullpath (without suffix) to the ags connection file ""C:\\path\\my_ags_server.ags"

member.summary: The CoordinateSystemsControl is a configurable control that provides a UI for Spatial Reference selection.
member.remarks: Optionally bind a CoordinateSystemControlProperties instance to the CoordinateSystemsControl to provide the desired configuration. A map, spatial reference, and show-vertical-coordinate-systems flag can be set. Developers can bind to the SelectedSpatialReference dependency property to receive selected spatial reference changed notifications and/or use a callback with the SelectedSpatialReferenceChanged event.

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Controls.CoordinateSystemsControlProperties
member.summary: Configures the properties to be used to initialize the CoordinateSystemsControl
member.remarks: To refresh the CoordinateSystemsControl (eg the map's layers change), provide an updated CoordinateSystemsControlProperties

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Controls.CoordinateSystemsControlProperties.#ctor
member.summary: Construct a CoordinateSystemsControlProperties to configure the CoordinateSystemsControl. Use the Map, SpatialReference (or Wkid or Wkt), and ShowVerticalCoordinateSystems properties to configure the control. They are all optional

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Controls.CoordinateSystemsControlProperties.Map
member.summary: Gets and sets the map whose layers will be used to populate the 'Layers' leaf in the CoordinateSystemsControl.
member.remarks: Map is optional. The default is null. If a map is set then its layers will populate the Layers leaf node in the CoordinateSystemsControl otherwise no layers are shown.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Controls.CoordinateSystemsControlProperties.SpatialReference
member.summary: Gets and sets the spatial reference to be used to select the SpatialReference in the CoordinateSystemsControl.
member.remarks:
SpatialReference is optional. The default is null. If the SpatialReference is set it will be selected in the CoordinateSystemsControl.
Note: only one of: o SpatialReference
o Wkid
o Wkt
need be set.
If the SpatialReference is set, Wkid and Wkt are ignored. If the SpatialReference is null, then Wkid is used. If the Wkid is 0 (or less), then the Wkt is used.
If no SpatialReference is set then the first SpatialReference of the first layer in the provided map is selected. If no map is provided then no SpatialReference is selected.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Controls.CoordinateSystemsControlProperties.Wkid
member.summary: Gets and sets the spatial reference wkid to be used to select the SpatialReference in the CoordinateSystemsControl.
member.remarks:
SpatialReference wkid is optional. The default is 0. If the SpatialReference wkid is set then the corresponding SpatialReference with that wkid will be selected in the CoordinateSystemsControl.
Note: only one of: o SpatialReference
o Wkid
o Wkt
need be set.
If the SpatialReference is set, Wkid and Wkt are ignored. If the SpatialReference is null, then Wkid is used. If the Wkid is 0 (or less), then the Wkt is used.
If no SpatialReference is set then the first SpatialReference of the first layer in the provided map is selected. If no map is provided then no SpatialReference is selected.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Controls.CoordinateSystemsControlProperties.Wkt
member.summary: Gets and sets the spatial reference wkt to be used to select the SpatialReference in the CoordinateSystemsControl.
member.remarks:
SpatialReference wkt is optional. The default is "" (or empty string). If the SpatialReference wkt is set then the corresponding SpatialReference with that wkt will be selected in the CoordinateSystemsControl.
Note: only one of: o SpatialReference
o Wkid
o Wkt
need be set.
If the SpatialReference is set, Wkid and Wkt are ignored. If the SpatialReference is null, then Wkid is used. If the Wkid is 0 (or less), then the Wkt is used.
If no SpatialReference is set then the first SpatialReference of the first layer in the provided map is selected. If no map is provided then no SpatialReference is selected.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Controls.CoordinateSystemsControlProperties.ShowVerticalCoordinateSystems
member.summary: Gets and sets the ShowVerticalCoordinateSystems setting. If this is set to true, the VerticalCoordinateSystems leaf node is shown in the CoordinateSystemsControl UI
member.remarks: The default is false. When false the ProjectedCoordinateSystems and GeographicCoordinateSystems leaf nodes are shown and not the VerticalCoordinateSystems node.

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Controls.CoordinateSystemsControlProperties.ConstructPickerProperties
member.summary: Construct a CoordinateSystemPickerProperties for the internal CoordinateSystemPicker control from the CoordinateSystemsControlProperties set by the 3rd party
member.returns: A CoordinateSystemPickerProperties

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Controls.QueryBuilderControlProperties
member.summary: Configures the properties to be used to initialize the QueryBuilderControl.
member.remarks: To refresh the QueryBuilderControl (eg the map's layers change), provide an updated QueryBuilderControlProperties.

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Controls.QueryBuilderControlProperties.#ctor
member.summary: Construct a QueryBuilderControlProperties to configure the QueryBuilderControl. Use the MapMember and Expression properties to configure the control. The MapMember property is required.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Controls.QueryBuilderControlProperties.MapMember
member.summary: Gets and sets the mapmember to be used in the QueryBuilderControl.
member.remarks: MapMember is required.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Controls.QueryBuilderControlProperties.Expression
member.summary: Gets and sets the query expression in the QueryBuilderControl.
member.remarks: Expression is optional. The default is empty. If the Expression is set it will be pre-populated in the QueryBuilderControl.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Controls.QueryBuilderControlProperties.AutoValidate
member.summary: Gets and sets the auto validation flag in the QueryBuilderControl.
member.remarks: The default is false meaning that validation must occur manually by the user clicking the Validate button or using the ValidateExpression API call.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Controls.QueryBuilderControlProperties.EditClauseMode
member.summary: Gets and sets the expression mode of the QueryBuilderControl. Setting EditClauseMode true means that the control displays the expression in clauses; a value of false displays the expression as a single SQL string.
member.remarks: The default is true.

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Controls.QueryBuilderControlProperties.ConstructBuilderExpression
member.summary: Construct a QueryBuilderExpression for the internal QueryBuilderControlInternal control from the QueryBuilderControlProperties set by the 3rd party.
member.returns: A QueryBuilderExpression

member.summary: Gets the current query expression.

member.summary: Callback for the ExpressionChanged event of the QueryBuilderControl.
member.param: The QueryBuilderControl instance.
An ExpressionChangedEventArgs with the current query expression.

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Controls.QueryBuilderControl
member.summary: The QueryBuilderControl is a configurable control that provides a UI for building a query expression against a layer or table.
member.remarks: Bind a QueryBuilderControlProperties instance to the QueryBuilderControl to provide the desired configuration. A mapMember (layer or table) must be set. An optional Expression can also be set. Developers can use a callback with the ExpressionChanged event to receive expression changed notifications. The ValidateExpression method is also available to validate the current query expression.
member.summary: QueryBuilderControl

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.StreamLayer
member.summary: Represents layer with a collection of real-time features and their visual representation.

remarks.para: Stream layer is a type of .To create a StreamLayer, you must call CreateLayer method of the LayerFactory class, instead of directly using a constructor.

When you use , you need to pass in a . You should set and in a only when the source stream service has associated archieved feature service layer. See for details. That is because at the creation time a stream layer starts with empty set of features.
You can call anytime later once you have sufficient features to compute and assign a or to a stream layer.

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.StreamLayer.GetExpirationMaxAge
member.summary: Gets the expiration maximum age for features. This method must be called on the MCT. Use QueuedTask.Run.
member.remarks: When is true, ExpirationMaxAge represents the maximum age within each track. Previous observations older than the maximum expiration age, compared to the latest observation in the same track, will be removed. When is false, features older than the maximum expiration age, comparing to the current time, will get removed.
member.returns: The indicating the ExpirationMaxAge
member.exception: This method or property must be called within the lambda passed to QueuedTask.Run.
Stream service data connection is null.

member.summary: Gets the expiration maximum feature count. This method must be called on the MCT. Use QueuedTask.Run.
member.remarks: When is true, ExpirationMaxCount represents the maximum number of features that will be stored per track. Otherwise, it represents the maximum number of features.
member.returns: The indicating the ExpirationMaxCount
member.exception: This method or property must be called within the lambda passed to QueuedTask.Run.

member.summary: Gets the current expiration method. This method must be called on the MCT. Use QueuedTask.Run.

Stream service data connection is null.

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.StreamLayer.SetExpirationMaxAge(System.TimeSpan)
member.summary: Sets the expiration maximum age for features. This method must be called on the MCT. Use QueuedTask.Run.
member.remarks:
must be set to or the maximum age is ignored. When is true, ExpirationMaxAge represents the maximum age within each track. Previous observations older than the maximum expiration age, compared to the latest observation in the same track, will be removed. When is false, features older than the maximum expiration age, comparing to the current time, will get removed. The stream layer uses a FIFO method - the first observation in is the first one to be removed and so on. To prevent any features from being removed, set ExpirationMaxAge to 0.
Note: When a stream layer is track-aware, use to set how many previous observations will be displayed on the map. Whereas SetExpirationMaxAge defines how many previous observation will be stored in memory.
member.param: The indicating features older than this value will be removed.
member.exception: This method or property must be called within the lambda passed to QueuedTask.Run.
Stream service data connection is null.

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.StreamLayer.SetExpirationMaxCount(System.UInt64)
member.summary: Gets the expiration maximum feature count. This method must be called on the MCT. Use QueuedTask.Run.
member.param: The values indicating how many features will be stored at any given time.
member.remarks:
must be set to or the maximum feature count is ignored. When is true, ExpirationMaxCount represents the maximum number of features that will be stored per track. Otherwise, it represents the maximum number of features that will be stored period. The stream layer uses a FIFO method - the first observation in is the first one to be removed and so on. To prevent any features from being removed, set ExpirationMaxCount to 0.
When a stream layer is track-aware, use to set how many will be displayed on the map. Whereas SetExpirationMaxCount defines how many previous observation will be stored in memory.

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.StreamLayer.Subscribe(ArcGIS.Core.Data.QueryFilter,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Subscribe to receive row events. This method must be called on the MCT. Use QueuedTask.Run.
member.remarks: Use to subscribe on any thread. As opposed to , this method does not perform a Search before subscribing. As a consequence, the returned will only iterate over rows that became available immediately after the execution of this method. If no query filter is set, all rows that become available will be retrieved.
member.param: A null query filter will cause all rows that become available to be retrieved.
If set to true, all the entries in will reference the most current row returned by . To ensure all the entries in remain unique, set to false. The default is true.
member.returns: A that encapsulates the retrieved rows, as well as provides facilities to wait for new row events.
member.exception: This method or property must be called within the lambda passed to QueuedTask.Run.
Stream Layer was disconnected from its underlying feature class.
A geodatabase-related exception has occurred.

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.StreamLayer.SearchAndSubscribe(ArcGIS.Core.Data.QueryFilter,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Searches the table for existing rows using the query criteria and then subscribes to receive row events. This method must be called on the MCT. Use QueuedTask.Run.
member.remarks: This operation is atomic. It is guaranteed that the returned will correctly reflect any insert or delete operations that occured at any time during the exection of this method. Use to search and subscribe on any thread. If no query filter is set, all pre-existing rows will be searched and all rows that become available after subscribing will be retrieved.
member.param: A null query filter will search all rows and all rows that become available will be retrieved.
If set to true, all the entries in will reference the most current row returned by . To ensure all the entries in remain unique, set to false. The default is true.
member.returns: A that encapsulates the retrieved rows, as well as provides facilities to wait for new row events.

member.summary: An enumeration to represent classification codes for a point cloud filter.

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.ClassificationFlags
member.summary: An enumeration to represent classification flags for a point cloud filter.

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.ClassFlagOption
member.summary: Enumeration to represent options for classification flags for a point cloud filter.
member.remarks: Included: All points with this flag will be displayed and points that do not have this flag will not be displayed. The check makes it an absolute requirement to have this flag in order to be displayed. Excluded: Points with this flag will never be displayed. Ignored: This flag does not contribute to point filtering. Points with this flag will be displayed, but if a point that does not have this flag is represented by another flag that is set to be displayed, then points that do not have this flag can also be displayed. This is the default.

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.ClassFlag
member.summary: Represents a classification flag for a point cloud filter.
member.remarks: When a classification is carried out on lidar data, points may fall into more than one category of the classification. Classification flags are used to provide a secondary description or classification for lidar points.

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.PointCloudFilterDefinition
member.summary: Represents a definition for a point cloud filter.
member.remarks: The point cloud filter definition class allows you to define parameters to create a point cloud filter. Once you define a filter, you can call PointCloudSceneLayers's CreateFilters and SetFilters methods to create and assign a filter to a point cloud layer.

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.PointCloudFilterDefinition.#ctor
member.summary: Creates an empty PointCloudFilterDefinition.

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.PointCloudFilterDefinition.#ctor(System.Collections.Generic.List{System.Int32},System.Collections.Generic.List{ArcGIS.Core.CIM.PointCloudReturnType},System.Collections.Generic.List{ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.ClassFlag})
member.summary: Creates a PointCloudFilterDefinition.
member.remarks: PointCloudFilterDefinition uses classification codes, return values, and classification flags to filter the point cloud data being rendered. Classification codes are used to define the type of surface, or surfaces, that reflected the lidar pulse. Return values correspond to the value stored in the RETURNS field of a point cloud and are typically influenced by the height of each surface that was scanned. Classification flags are a secondary description of the lidar pulses (in addition to their classification code).
member.param: A list of one or more classification codes

member.remarks: Classification flag values provide a secondary description of the point cloud data (beyond their classification code). Flags include Synthetic, key-point, withheld, and overlap. member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.PointCloudSceneLayer.QueryAvailablePointCloudRendererFields(ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.PointCloudRendererType)
member.summary: Queries the available fields for the specified renderer type. This method must be called on the MCT. Use QueuedTask.Run
member.param: Input renderer type
member.remarks:
Each renderer type requires different fields be present on the point cloud layer. If an empty list is returned from QueryAvailablePointCloudRendererFields for a given renderer type then it means that that particular renderer type is not supported for the given PointCloudSceneLayer.
If the renderer type is supported then one of the field names returned in the list must be set as the value when defining the new renderer to be used.
Setting an invalid renderer on the layer will disable rendering of the layer until it is removed
member.returns: IReadOnlyList{ }
member.exception: This method or property must be called within the lambda passed to QueuedTask.Run.

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.ExportFormat
member.summary: Provides a base set of properties that all export formats inherit.

remarks.para: When exporting a MapView, the size of the output image is based on the Resolution and the Height and Width properties. For example, if the output resolution is 96 and height and width are both 960 then the output image size will be 960 pixels by 960 pixels and 10 inches by 10 inches. The geographic area for an exported MapView is generated based on its location which represents the center of the view.

When exporting a Layout or a MapFrame, the height and width are obtained from the size of the object in page units and the Height and Width properties are ignored. For example, if a MapFrame is 5 inches by 5 inches and the resolution is 300, the output image will be 1500 pixels by 1500 pixels and remain 5 inches by 5 inches.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.ExportFormat.OutputFileName
member.summary: Gets or sets a string that represents the path and file name for the output export file.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.ExportFormat.Resolution
member.summary: Gets or sets a number that defines the resolution of the export file in dots per inch (DPI).
member.remarks: (The default value is 96)

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.ExportFormat.Width
member.summary: Gets or sets the number of pixels that represents the width of the output file.

remarks.para: This property only applies to exporting map views. The value is ignored when exporting layouts or map frames.
(The default value is 960)

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.ExportFormat.Height
member.summary: Gets or sets the number of pixels that represents the height of the output file.

remarks.para: This property only applies to exporting map views. The value is ignored when exporting layouts or map frames.
(The default value is 960)

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.ExportFormat.DoClipToGraphicExtent
member.summary: Get and sets if the layout is clipped to the smallest bounding box that encompasses all layout elements.

remarks.para: This property only applies to exporting layouts. The value is ignored when exporting map views or map frames.
(The default value is false)

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.ExportFormat.ValidateOutputFilePath
member.summary: Provides a way to test the validity of the output path before setting it to a location that may not be valid.

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.BMPFormat
member.summary: Represents a Microsoft Windows Bitmap (BMP) object that can be used to export a MapView, MapFrame, or a Layout.
member.remarks: BMP files are simple, native Windows raster images. In general, BMPs are much larger than formats such as JPEG or PNG. They do not scale as well as vector files and may appear blocky or jagged when increased in size. BMPs can be generated with an accompanying world file for use as georeferenced raster data.
member.example: The following examples demonstrate how to export a Layout, a MapFrame, and a MapView to BMP format.

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.BMPFormat.#ctor
member.summary: Initialize a new instance of BMPFormat.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.BMPFormat.HasColorProfile
member.summary: Specifies the if color profile is embeded.

remarks.para: The values available are defined in .
(The default value is false)

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.BMPFormat.HasWorldFile
member.summary: Gets or sets if a georeferenced world file will be created.

remarks.para: If set to true, the file will contain pixel scale and real-world coordinate information. World files are not generated for Layout exports.
If you export a 3D view, this parameter will be ignored regardless of the setting because world files are not applicable to 3D views.
(The default value is false)

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.BMPFormat.ColorMode
member.summary: Specifies the number of bits used to describe color.

remarks.para: The values available are defined in .
(The default value is 24-bit True Color)
ThirtyTwoBitWithAlpha is NOT supported

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.BMPFormat.BMPImageCompression
member.summary: Gets or sets a String that defines the compression scheme used to compress image or raster data in the output file.

remarks.para: The values available are defined in .
(The default value is Adaptive)

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.EMFFormat
member.summary: Represents an Enhanced Metafile Format (EMF) object that can be used to export a MapView, MapFrame, or a Layout.
member.remarks: EMF files are native Windows graphics files that can contain a mixture of vector and raster data. They are useful for embedding in Windows documents because the vector portions of the EMF can be resized without loss of quality. However, since EMF does not support font embedding and is exclusively a Windows format, it is not commonly used as an interchange format between users.
member.example: The following examples demonstrate how to export a Layout, a MapFrame, and a MapView to EMF format.

member.summary: Initialize a new instance of EMFFormat.

member.summary: Gets or sets a string that defines output image quality - the draw resolution of map layers that draw as rasters.

remarks.para: The values available are defined in .
(The default value is Best)

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.EMFFormat.DoFullRasterization
member.summary: Gets or sets a Boolean that controls the full rasterization in export file.
member.remarks: (The default value is false)

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.EPSFormat
member.summary: Represents an Encapsulated Postscript (EPS) object that can be used to export a MapView, MapFrame, or a Layout.
member.remarks: EPS files use the PostScript page description language to describe vector and raster objects. PostScript is the publishing industry standard for high-end graphics files, cartography, and printing. EPS files can be edited in many drawing applications or placed as a graphic in most page layout applications. EPS files support embedding of fonts so that users who do not have Esri Fonts installed can still view the proper symbology.
member.example: The following examples demonstrate how to export a Layout, a MapFrame, and a MapView to EPS format.

member.summary: Gets or sets a string that defines output image quality - the draw resolution of map layers that draw as rasters.

(The default value is Best)

member.summary: Gets or sets a Boolean that controls the embedding of fonts in the export file.
member.remarks: (The default value is true)

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.EPSFormat.ImageCompression
member.summary: Gets or sets a String that defines the compression scheme used to compress image or raster data in the output file.

remarks.para: The values available are defined in .
(The default value is Adaptive)

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.EPSFormat.ImageCompressionQuality
member.summary: This value (0100) controls the amount of compression applied to the output image. With a JPEG image, quality is adversely affected the more compression is applied. A higher quality (highest = 100) setting will produce sharper images and larger file sizes. A lower quality setting will produce more image artifacts and smaller files.
member.remarks: (The default value is 80)

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.EPSFormat.DoFullRasterization
member.summary: Gets or sets a Boolean that controls the full rasterization in export file.
member.remarks: (The default value is false)

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.GIFFormat
member.summary: Represents an Graphic Interchange Format (GIF) object that can be used to export a MapView, MapFrame, or a Layout.
member.remarks: GIF files are a legacy raster format for use on the web. GIFs cannot contain more than 256 colors (8-bits per pixel), which along with optional lossless compression, makes them smaller than other file formats.
member.example: The following examples demonstrate how to export a Layout, a MapFrame, and a MapView to GIF format.

member.summary: Initialize a new instance of GIFFormat.

remarks.para: The values available are defined in .
(The default value is 8-bit Adaptive Palette)

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.GIFFormat.HasWorldFile
member.summary: Gets or sets if a georeferenced world file will be created.

remarks.para: If set to true, the file will contain pixel scale and real-world coordinate information. World files are not generated for Layout exports.
If you export a 3D view, this parameter will be ignored regardless of the setting because world files are not applicable to 3D views.
(The default value is false)

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.JPEGFormat
member.summary: Represents a Joint Photographic Experts Group (JPEG) format object that can be used to export a MapView, MapFrame, or a Layout.
member.remarks: JPEG files are compressed image files. They support 24-bit color and are a popular choice for use on the web because a JPEG file size is often substantially smaller than many other image formats. However, the JPEG compression algorithm is lossy and is not recommended for many map images, as line drawings, and text or icon graphics become blurred by compression artifacts. Therefore, PNG is usually a superior format for map images. JPEGs can be generated with an accompanying world file for use as georeferenced raster data.
member.example: The following examples demonstrate how to export a Layout, a MapFrame, and a MapView to JPEG format.

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.JPEGFormat.#ctor
member.summary: Initialize a new instance of JPEGFormat.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.JPEGFormat.ImageCompressionQuality
member.summary: This value (0100) controls the amount of compression applied to the output image. With a JPEG image, quality is adversely affected the more compression is applied. A higher quality (highest = 100) setting will produce sharper images and larger file sizes. A lower quality setting will produce more image artifacts and smaller files.
member.remarks: (The default value is 80)

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.JPEGFormat.HasWorldFile
member.summary: Gets or sets if a georeferenced world file will be created.

remarks.para: If set to true, the file will contain pixel scale and real-world coordinate information. World files are not generated for Layout exports.
If you export a 3D view, this parameter will be ignored regardless of the setting because world files are not applicable to 3D views.
(The default value is false)

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.PDFFormat
member.summary: Represents a Portable Document Format (PDF) object that can be used to export a MapView, MapFrame, or a Layout.
member.remarks: PDF files are designed to be consistently viewable and printable across different platforms. They are commonly used for distributing documents on the Web and are becoming a standard interchange format for content delivery. PDFs are editable in many graphics applications and can retain annotation, labeling, and attribute data for map layers. PDF exports from support embedding of fonts and thus can display symbology correctly even if the user does not have Esri fonts installed.
member.example: The following examples demonstrate how to export a Layout, a MapFrame, and a MapView to PDF format.

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.PNGFormat
member.summary: Represents a Portable Network Graphics (PNG) object that can be used to export a MapView, MapFrame, or a Layout.
member.remarks: PNG is a versatile raster format that can display in web browsers and inserted into other documents. It supports high-bit-depth color and uses a lossless compression. For maps, PNG is often the best raster format, since the lossless compression keeps text and line work legible by preventing the compression artifacts that can occur in JPEG format. PNGs can be generated with an accompanying world file for use as georeferenced raster data.
member.example: The following examples demonstrate how to export a Layout, a MapFrame, and a MapView to PNG format.

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.PNGFormat.#ctor

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.PNGFormat.HasWorldFile
member.summary: Gets or sets if a georeferenced world file will be created.

remarks.para: If set to true, the file will contain pixel scale and real-world coordinate information. World files are not generated for Layout exports.
If you export a 3D view, this parameter will be ignored regardless of the setting because world files are not applicable to 3D views.
(The default value is false)

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.SVGFormat
member.summary: Represents a Scalable Vector Graphics (SVG) object that can be used to export a MapView, MapFrame, or a Layout.
member.remarks: SVG is an XML-based file format that has been specifically designed for viewing on the Web. SVG can contain both vector and raster information. This is a good choice for displaying maps on a web page because it is rescalable and more easily edited than raster files. SVG has been gaining in popularity since the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) selected it as their standard vector Web format. Some Web browsers may require a plug-in to view SVG files; older browsers may not be able to view SVG files at all.
member.example: The following examples demonstrate how to export a Layout, a MapFrame, and a MapView to SVG format.

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.TIFFFormat
member.summary: Represents a Tagged Image File Format (TIFF) object that can be used to export a MapView, MapFrame, or a Layout.
member.remarks: TIFF files are the most versatile raster format. TIFFs can store pixel data at several bit depths and can be compressed with either lossy or loss less compression techniques depending on file size and accuracy requirements. They are the best choice for importing into image editing applications across operating systems. They cannot be natively viewed by a web browser. TIFFs exported from a Map or MapFrame also support georeferencing information in GeoTIFF tags or in a separate world file for use as raster data.
member.example: The following examples demonstrate how to export a Layout, a MapFrame, and a MapView to TIFF format.

If you export a 3D view, this parameter will be ignored regardless of the setting because world files are not applicable to 3D views.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.TIFFFormat.ImageCompressionQuality
member.summary: This value (0100) controls the amount of compression applied to the output image. With a JPEG image, quality is adversely affected the more compression is applied. A higher quality (highest = 100) setting will produce sharper images and larger file sizes. A lower quality setting will produce more image artifacts and smaller files.
member.remarks: (The default value is 100)

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.AIXFormat
member.summary: Represents a Portable Document Format (AIX) object that can be used to export a MapView, MapFrame, or a Layout.
member.remarks: AIX files are designed to be consistently viewable and printable across different platforms. They are commonly used for distributing documents on the Web and are becoming a standard interchange format for content delivery. AIXs are editable in many graphics applications and can retain annotation, labeling, and attribute data for map layers. AIX exports from support embedding of fonts and thus can display symbology correctly even if the user does not have Esri fonts installed.

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Snapping
member.summary: Provides access to the snapping environment.

remarks.para: Changing the property has immediate effect, and saved into user preferences.
Changing the snapping modes, via or also has immediate effect, applied to all project s, and saved into user preferences.
You can obtain a copy of the for a particular using . Changes made to the resulting object, are not immediately made to the system until the copy is committed to the project using .

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Snapping.SetSnapModes(ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.SnapMode[])
member.param: a variable set of zero or more (comma-separated) SnapMode parameters expressed either as an array or as a variable length argument list
member.remarks: This method disables the current snapping modes and enables the given snapping modes. It is intended to efficiently set one or more snapping modes.

example.code: Snapping.SetSnapModes(SnapMode.Midpoint); // sets only the Midpoint snapping mode Snapping.SetSnapModes(SnapMode.Point, SnapMode.Edge); // sets only Point and Edge snapping modes Snapping.SetSnapModes(); //clear all snap modes

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Snapping.GetSnapMode(ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.SnapMode)
member.summary: Gets the state of a single SnapMode.

example.code: //obtain Midpoint snapping state var isSnapModeMidpoint = Snapping.GetSnapMode(SnapMode.Midpoint);

summary.para: Sets the state of a single SnapMode.

example.code: //ensure Midpoint snapping is switched on Snapping.SetSnapMode(SnapMode.Midpoint, true);

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Snapping.GetOptions(ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Map)
member.summary: Gets the snapping options for the specified map. This method must be called on the MCT. Use QueuedTask.Run
member.remarks: Snapping options are stored within the CIM.
member.returns: The snapping options, or null if something went wrong trying to read the CIM snapping options
member.exception: if map is null
This method or property must be called within the lambda passed to QueuedTask.Run.

example.code: var options = Snapping.GetOptions(map); // obtains a local copy of the options options.ZToleranceEnabled = true; // change the ZToleranceEnabled property within the local copy Snapping.SetOptions(map, options); //commits the local copy into the project

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Snapping.SetOptions(ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Map,ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.SnappingOptions)
member.summary: Sets the snapping options for the specified map. This method must be called on the MCT. Use QueuedTask.Run
member.param: a SnappingOptions object that was obtained using
member.exception: if either of options or map is null
This method or property must be called within the lambda passed to QueuedTask.Run.

example.code: var options = Snapping.GetOptions(map); // obtains a local copy of the options options. ZToleranceEnabled = true; // change the ZToleranceEnabled property within the local copy Snapping.SetOptions(map, options); //commits the local copy into the project

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.MapFactory.ConvertMap(ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Map,ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.MapConversionType,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Convert the input map to the specified output type. This method must be called on the MCT. Use QueuedTask.Run.
member.remarks:
The following conversions are supported: o Map -> Base map, Scene (Global), Scene (Local)
o BaseMap -> Map
o Scene (Global) -> Map
o Scene (Local) -> Map
Technically, there is no difference between the Scene (Global) or Scene (Local). It merely indicates the nature or their underlying coordinate system (i.e. "global" or "local").
The intended conversion can be tested by calling the method first.
Specifying openView=true will open a new view for the converted map. The method will return without waiting for the view to initialize and begin drawing. This is an optimization to prevent Pro being loaded down with viewer initialization if this method is called within a loop to create multiple maps. The correct way to detect viewer initialization is via the . The event will fire after the first draw of the new view has been initiated.
member.param: The map to convert
The type to convert the map to
true to open a map pane for the newly converted map
member.returns: The converted
member.exception: This method or property must be called within the lambda passed to QueuedTask.Run.
Cannot convert {map} to {conversion type}
Failed to convert the map viewing mode

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.MapFactory.ConvertMapFromItem(ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.MapProjectItem,ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.MapConversionType,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Convert the input map item to the specified output type. This method must be called on the MCT. Use QueuedTask.Run.
member.remarks:
The following conversions are supported (the map referenced by the map item is tested): o Map -> Base map, Scene (Global), Scene (Local)
o BaseMap -> Map
o Scene (Global) -> Map
o Scene (Local) -> Map
Technically, there is no difference between the Scene (Global) or Scene (Local). It merely indicates the nature or their underlying coordinate system (i.e. "global" vs "local").
The intended conversion can be tested by calling the method first.
Specifying openView=true will open a new view for the converted map (in the item). The method will return without waiting for the view to initialize and begin drawing. This is an optimization to prevent Pro being loaded down with viewer initialization if this method is called within a loop to create multiple maps. The correct way to detect viewer initialization is via the . The event will fire after the first draw of the new view has been initiated.
member.param: The map item to convert
The type to convert the map item to
true to open a map pane for the newly converted map item
member.returns: The converted
member.exception: This method or property must be called within the lambda passed to QueuedTask.Run.

Failed to convert the map viewing mode

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.MapFactory.CanConvertMap(ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Map,ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.MapConversionType)
member.summary: Test whether the map can be converted to the specified output type. This method must be called on the MCT. Use QueuedTask.Run.
member.remarks:
The following conversions are supported: o Map -> Base map, Scene (Global), Scene (Local)
o BaseMap -> Map
o Scene (Global) -> Map
o Scene (Local) -> Map
Specifying an invalid conversion type will return false
Note: If MapConversionType.SceneGlobal is specified, if the map spatial reference contains a vertical coordinate system, the VCS is checked to see if it is compatible with a global scene. If it is not, the method will also return false
member.param: The map to test
The type to convert the map to
member.exception: This method or property must be called within the lambda passed to QueuedTask.Run.

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.SurfaceZsMissingHandler
member.summary: Defines how Z values will be handled for input Geometries or their vertices that do not lie within the bounds of the input Surface.
member.remarks:
The default behavior for all overrides of is:
All input geometry vertex Z values are initially reset to as a placeholder for the software when determining which Zs have yet to be successfully calculated.
The Z for each vertex is calculated based on its position relative to the surface.
After attempting to calculate the Z for all vertices, any Zs that are still NaN are considered "missing" and assigned the value of .
There may be situations where you only want to overwrite a particular subset of the input geometry vertex Z values. In this case you can use a combination of the OnlyProcessMissingZs and InputZ parameters to identify the Z values to be processed:
preset the required input geometry vertex Zs to a constant value - double.NaN can work, but there may be some other data-appropriate number.
set the equal to the chosen constant value.
set the value of to true.
Only those input Zs whose value is equal to the value of InputZ (within the precision limits of the spatial reference) will be overwritten. Only those Zs will have a Z value calculated from the surface (or set to the value of OutputZ if they fall outside the surface extent.) See also:

member.name: F:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.SurfaceZsMissingHandler.DefaultOutputZ
member.summary: 0.0 is the default for

member.name: F:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.SurfaceZsMissingHandler.DefaultInputZ
member.summary: double.NaN is the default for

member.name: F:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.SurfaceZsMissingHandler.DefaultOnlyProcessMissingZs
member.summary: false is the default for

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.SurfaceZsMissingHandler.InputZ
member.summary: Gets and sets the input geometry Z value that is considered to be missing.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.SurfaceZsMissingHandler.OutputZ
member.summary: Gets and sets the output value that will replace all missing input Z values

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.SurfaceZsMissingHandler.OnlyProcessMissingZs
member.summary: Gets and sets whether or not all input Z values will be processed, or only the input Z values that are determined to be missing

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Animation
member.summary: Represents the collection of tracks, keyframes and transitions that define an animation for the map.

remarks.para: Animation is the process of creating a collection of sequential images and playing them back quickly to create an illusion of movement. Each image, just like a picture you take with a camera, marks a significant instance in time, and is called a keyframe. In ArcGIS Pro, animations are authored by defining a set of keyframes that the system uses to create interpolated intermediate frames. Animations can interpolate the camera position, map time, map range, and layer visibility and transparency.
An instance of this class is returned from the property and can be used to manipulate the state of the animation by creating, editing and deleting keyframes.

code.title: Create a new camera keyframe
code.description: Create a new camera keyframe from the active map view.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Animation.Tracks
member.summary: Gets and sets the list of tracks in the animation.
member.remarks: A track stores the collection of keyframes whose values and transitions define the interpolated values for each frame of the animation. This property will always return 4 tracks and specifically it will contain one , , and . Each track type stores a corresponding keyframe for that type and is used to animate either the camera position, map time, map range, or layer visibility and transparency. The duration of the animation is equal to the time of the last keyframe in all tracks. The animation is removed from the map by deleting all keyframes in all tracks.

code.title: Get the Camera Keyframes from the Animation
code.description: Get the Camera Keyframes from the Animation.

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.BasicFeatureLayer.Search(ArcGIS.Core.Data.QueryFilter)
member.summary: Executes a spatial or attribute query to the underlying data source and returns features matching the search criteria. For stream layer, you should call for predictable result. This method must be called on the MCT. Use QueuedTask.Run.
member.param: A query filter or spatial filter to perform spatial search.
member.returns: A RowCursor (you can cast it to FeatureCursor) allows access to the matched features.
member.exception: This method or property must be called within the lambda passed to QueuedTask.Run.

remarks.para:
If there is a definition query set on the feature layer, the Search() method will automatically work on the subset of features in the feature layer that meet the definition criteria. You specify an additional query that will be applied after the feature layer's definition query by passing valid QueryFilter object for the QueryFilter parameter.
If the feature layer has any joins, this Search() method takes that into account.
You can use the cursor returned by Search to update features.
To ensure maximum robustness, callers should explicitly dispose of the returned in either a using statement or a finally block.
For stream layers, especially with high velocity real-time updates, features might get expired (removed) while you are looping through feature cursor.

code.title: Querying a feature layer
code.description: Querying a feature layer.

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.ExploratoryAnalysis
member.summary: The abstract base class for all Exploratory Analysis types. Used to create a manage a common collection of all Exploratory Analysis objects

remarks.para: 3D Exploratory Analysis is a suite of interactive tools for performing various forms of quick investigation by interactively creating graphics and editing analysis parameters on-the-fly. Real-time visual feedback is provided in the scene.

A collection of existing Exploratory Analysis objects can be queried with which returns a collection of ExploratoryAnalysisBase objects. You can cast each object to its appropriate subclass to work with it.

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.ExploratoryAnalysis.#ctor
member.summary: Base class constructor

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.ExploratoryAnalysis.Id
member.summary:
Identifier for the exploratory analysis object within its current MapView.
The ID is only unique to the map view that it was added to. For this reason, the same instance should not be added to more than one MapView. Use the subclass's copy constructor for that.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.ExploratoryAnalysis.MapView
member.summary: The current MapView that this exploratory analysis object is in.

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.ViewDome
member.summary:
View domes are used to conduct visibility analysis as a sphere extending out from an observer point. A sphere is created representing the visiblity extent. The sphere is painted to represent that parts of the sphere that are visible to the observer or obstructed.
View domes can be used to model real-world objects such as a viewing platform or a radar station.

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.ViewDome.#ctor(ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Camera,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: The default ViewDome constructor.
member.param: A Camera object used for position of the observer. Must be in the target map's .
Defines a near distance limit in meters. Any scene content closer than this value is disregarded.
Defines a far distance limit and size of the view dome in meters. Any scene content far than this value is disregarded.

member.summary:

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Viewshed
member.summary:
Viewsheds are used to conduct visibility analysis within a view frustrum of an observer point. A wireframe of the view frustum is is created and geomtry within the frustrum is tinted to represent the features visible to the observer or obstructed.
Viewsheds can be used to model real-world objects like cameras, human patrol agents, or radar stations.

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Viewshed.#ctor(ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Camera,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: The default Viewshed constructor.
member.param: A Camera object used for position, heading, and pitch of the observer. Must be in the target map's .
The observer's vertical field of view angle in degrees. Valid values: 0-180.
The observer's horizontal field of view angle in degrees. Valid values: 0-360
Defines a near distance limit in meters. Any scene content closer than this value is disregarded.
Defines a far distance limit and size of the view dome in meters. Any scene content far than this value is disregarded.

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.LineOfSight
member.summary:
LineOfSight are used to conduct visibility analysis for direct lines from an observer point to one or more targets.
An observer and one or more targets are created with lines connecting the target(s) to the observer. The line segements and targets are painted using the Visible and NotVisible colors if they can be seen by the observer of if the view is obstructed.
Lines of sight can be used to model real-world objects like visibility to points of interest or rough approximations for projectile trajectories.

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.LineOfSight.#ctor(ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Camera,System.Collections.Generic.List{ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Camera},System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: The default LineOfSight constructor.
member.param: A Camera object used for position of the observer. Must be in the target map's .
A list of Camera objects used for the target points. At least one target is required. Must be in the target map's .
Defines a near distance limit in meters. Any scene content closer than this value is disregarded.
Defines a far distance limit and size of the view dome in meters. Any scene content far than this value is disregarded.

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.Keyframe
member.summary: Represents the base class for all keyframe types.

remarks.para: A keyframe is a visual way-point along the animation path in a map or scene. When an animation is played, values such as the location of the camera, the current map time, the current map range, and layer transparencies are interpolated between the stored states defined by the keyframe using a configurable transition type. The transition type defines how frames are interpolated between keyframes.

For example, let's say we have 2 keyframes in a track one at a time of 0 seconds and the second at a time of 3 seconds. The first keyframe has a value for X of 1 and the second keyframe has a value for X of 5. The second keyframe defines the transition for X as linear. What this means is at 0 seconds in the animation X is 1, at 3 seconds X is 5 and at 1.5 seconds or halfway between the value would be 3. Each keyframe may have one or more values it stores and a corresponding transition definition for each value.

code.title: Create a new camera keyframe
code.description: Create a new camera keyframe from the active map view.

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.IDisplayTable.Search(ArcGIS.Core.Data.QueryFilter)
member.summary: Executes a query to the underlying data source and returns rows matching the search criteria. This method must be called on the MCT. Use QueuedTask.Run.
member.returns: A RowCursor allows access to the matched rows.
member.exception: This method or property must be called within the lambda passed to QueuedTask.Run.

remarks.para:
If there is a definition query set on the MapMember, the Search() method will automatically work on the subset of rows in the MapMember that meet the definition criteria. You specify an additional query that will be applied after the MapMember's definition query by passing valid QueryFilter object for the QueryFilter parameter.
If the MapMember has any joins, this Search() method takes that into account.
You can use the cursor returned by Search to update rows.
To ensure maximum robustness, callers should explicitly dispose of the returned in either a using statement or a finally block.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.PopupContent.IsDynamicContent
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating if the content for the pop-up should be created the first time it is loaded in the window.
member.remarks: Use this option if you want to create the content for the pop-up dynamically when the item is displayed in the window. This is useful if you are going to be showing multiple items in the pop-up window and don't want to generate the content for the item until it is viewed in the window. To take advantage of this dynamic content creation you must derive from the PopupContent class and override the method. This method will be called the first time the content for the item is requested.

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.RendererDefinition
member.summary: Represents an abstract class definition for all types of renderers.
member.remarks:
RendererDefinition classes allow you to define parameters to create renderers to draw features with simple renderer or based on unique values or the values of a quantitative attribute that is statistically grouped by a classification algorithm.
Once you define a renderer, you can call a FeatureLayer's CreateRenderer and SetRenderer methods to create and assign a renderer to a feature layer.

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.ClassBreaksRendererDefinition
member.summary: Represents an abstract class definition for class breaks renderers.
member.remarks:
ClassBreaksRendererDefinition defines the parameters for drawing features based on the values of a quantitative attribute that is statistically grouped by a classification algorithm.
To set up a ClassBreaksRenderer you first need to know how many classes you will have. Then you specify a particular classification algorithm (e.g. natural breaks, quantile, equal interval) to your data to compute class breaks for your renderer. You provide The color ramp Once you define a renderer, you can call a FeatureLayer's CreateRenderer and SetRenderer methods to create and assign a renderer to a feature layer.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.ClassBreaksRendererDefinition.ClassificationField
member.summary: Gets or sets field name used in the renderer. This is required.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.ClassBreaksRendererDefinition.ClassificationMethod
member.summary: Gets and sets classification method to be used to compute class breaks. This is required.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.ClassBreaksRendererDefinition.BreakCount
member.summary: Gets or sets number of desired class breaks.
member.remarks: Optional, it does not apply when StandardDeviation or DefinedInterval is used as the classification method.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.ClassBreaksRendererDefinition.DeviationInterval
member.summary: Gets or set standard deviation interval.
member.remarks: Only applicable when ClassifcationMethod is StandardDeviation.

member.summary: Gets or sets the method be used to normalized data.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.ClassBreaksRendererDefinition.NormalizationField
member.summary: Gets or sets the field which will be used to normalize data when 'Field' is selected as the DataNormalizationMethod.

member.summary: Gets or sets a template for symbol used in the renderer.

member.summary: Gets or sets the color ramp be used to pick color for symbols from.

member.summary: Gets or sets the interval size.
member.remarks: Only applicable if ClassifcationMethod is set to DefinedInterval. When the value is <1, the interval size gets calculated automatically.

member.summary: Gets or sets a SQL statement to exclude features while computing class breaks.

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.UniqueValueRendererDefinition
member.summary: Represents unique value renderer definition to apply a different symbol to each category of feature within the layer based on one or more fields.
member.remarks:
UniqueValueRendererDefinition class allows you to define parameters to create renderers to draw features based on unique values.
Once you define a unique value renderer, you can call a FeatureLayer's CreateRenderer and SetRenderer methods to create and assign a renderer to a feature layer.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.UniqueValueRendererDefinition.ValueFields
member.summary: Gets or sets one or more fields be used to get unique values or combination of values from. This is required.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.UniqueValueRendererDefinition.FieldDelimiter
member.summary: Gets or sets a string to as delimiter while concatenating values from multiple fields.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.UniqueValueRendererDefinition.ColorRamp
member.summary: Gets or sets the color ramp be used to pick color for symbols from.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.UniqueValueRendererDefinition.SymbolTemplate
member.summary: Gets or sets a template for symbol used in the renderer.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.UniqueValueRendererDefinition.DefaultSymbol
member.summary: Gets or sets a symbol that will be used to draw features whose values are not found in values list.
member.remarks:
You should use this when there are more unique values that what you set as ValuesLimit.
Note, this is only applicable when UseDefaultSymbol is set to true.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.UniqueValueRendererDefinition.UseDefaultSymbol
member.summary: Gets or sets a boolean to indicate that DefaultSymbol will be used to draw features whose values are not found in the values list.
member.remarks: You should use this when there are more unique values that what you set as ValuesLimit.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.UniqueValueRendererDefinition.ValuesLimit
member.summary: Gets or sets a limit on how many unique values will be retrieved from the table.
member.remarks:
You can pass 0 to retrieve all unique values. By default it is set to 100.
When you set it to other than 0, you should set DefaultSymbol and UseDefaultSymbol so that you will miss any features from drawing.

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.GraduatedColorsRendererDefinition
member.summary: Represents graduated color renderer definition to show qualitative differences in feature values with a range of color.
member.remarks:
GraduatedColorsRendererDefinition class allow you to define parameters to create renderers to draw features with graduated color based on the values of a quantitative attribute that is statistically grouped by a classification algorithm.
Once you define a graduated color renderer, you can call a FeatureLayer's CreateRenderer and SetRenderer methods to create and assign a renderer to a feature layer.

(Optional) Statistical algorithm to compute breaks. (default value = NaturalaBreaks)

(Optional) A template for symbol used in the renderer.

member.name: T:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.GraduatedSymbolsRendererDefinition
member.summary: Represents graduated symbol renderer definition to show qualitative differences in feature values with varying symbol sizes.
member.remarks:
GraduatedSymbolsRendererDefinition class allow you to define parameters to create renderers to draw features with symbols with graduated size determined based on the values of a quantitative attribute that is statistically grouped by a classification algorithm.
Once you define a graduated symbol renderer, you can call a FeatureLayer's CreateRenderer and SetRenderer methods to create and assign a renderer to a feature layer.

member.name: P:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.ProportionalRendererDefinition.IsMaximumSymbolSizeCapped
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the maximum symbol size is capped.

member.name: M:ArcGIS.Desktop.Mapping.ProportionalRendererDefinition.#ctor(System.String,System.Double,System.Nullable{System.Double},System.Boolean)
member.summary: Creates a ProportionalRendererDefinition.
member.param: Name of the field used in the renderer.
(Optional) The minimum symbol size used in the renderer to draw features with lowest value. (default value = 4)

(Optional) The maximum symbol size used in the renderer to draw features with highest values. When a null value is passed in, a maximum symbol size gets automatically picked based on the layer's shape type. (default value = null)

(Optional) When false, maximumSymbolSize gets ignored and the size of the symbol is drawn proportional to the value. Otherwise, the largest symbol size is equal to maximumSymbolSize. (default value = true)

remarks.para: Use this constructor only when the map is in a Projected Coordinate System.

When the map is in a projected coordinated system and Units is set, use this constructor to symbolize features where the value of the feature gets used as the radius or the area of the symbol (depending on valueRepresentations).
